TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: told by Giłgiław of Vałulu village

S.FORM: aitsu a maretseketsekeł inika tadjalan a mamazangiłan katua qaqetitan.
aico a marecekecekelj inika tadjalan a mamazangiljan katoa qaqetitan.
S.TRANSL: Weddings of chieftains and commoners are not the same.

S.FORM: nu mamazangiłan marepaukuz aya.
no mamazangiljan marepaokoz aya.
S.TRANSL: With chieftains they are known as marepaukuz;

S.FORM: nu qaqetitan marepalikuz aya.
no qaqetitan marepalikoz aya.
aitsu a mamazangiłan nu qemayam tua sauzayan, papirava tua kama tua kina tua zua sirakeraketj.
aico a mamazangiljan no qemayam toa saozayan, papirava toa kama toa kina toa zoa sirakeraketj.
S.TRANSL: In the case of the chieftains when they inspect the possessions offered as a bride price, they dress the father and the mother of (the bride) the cause of all-day celebrations.

S.FORM: nu uqałay gamuts ḍeqer tjakit kuang siatj paledeled a sipapirava.
no oqaljay gamoc dreqer tjakit koang siatj paledeled a sipapirava.
S.TRANSL: A male is dressed in a headdress (with wild boars’ tusks), necklace, sword, gun, bandolier and belt.

S.FORM: nu vavayan quvał tarar vatsvats ḍeqer kava kun tjukap a sipapirava.
no vavayan qovalj tarar vacvac dreqer kava kon tjokap a sipapirava.
S.TRANSL: A female is dressed in a fur coat, turban, pendant earrings, necklace, robe, skirt and shoes.

S.FORM: qau nu kavusaman papiravan a kama a kina azua ałak a vavayan.
qao no kavosaman papiravan a kama a kina azoa aljak a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: And when it is a head chieftain father, mother and daughter are all dressed.

S.FORM: łakua inika mapasusu a penułat.
ljakoa inika mapasoso a penoljat.
S.TRANSL: But these customs are not always carried out.

S.FORM: sauzayan anga a mamadjeledjelean, paisu anga a sipapirava.
saozayan anga a mamadjeledjelean, paiso anga a sipapirava.
S.TRANSL: Cheaper possessions or money may be given instead of dressing the people.

S.FORM: nu uri marepaukuz seman rarukuzan nu katiatiaw, sana parepaukuz.
no ori marepaokoz seman rarokozan no katiatiaw, sana parepaokoz.
S.TRANSL: When a wedding is to take place, preparations of food etc (which confirm the agreement(?)) are made the day before, and then the wedding goes ahead.

S.FORM: nu małianga marepakaiv, sana łayuz.
no maljianga marepakaiv, sana ljayoz.
S.TRANSL: Next day there is an exchange of drinks (at a feast); then there is a love song (at which the bride weeps).

S.FORM: nu łemayuz mana siqunevunevuł a sangasangasan.
no ljemayoz mana siqonevonevolj a sangasangasan.
S.TRANSL: When the song is sung there is the first distribution of small gifts to all.

S.FORM: nu małianga kiulaw anga a sema tsemtsemel.
no maljianga kiolaw anga a sema cemcemel.
S.TRANSL: The next day the bride hides herself in the woods.

S.FORM: nu masulem nu mangtjez anga qemunevuł anga uta tua sikinmusał.
no masolem no mangtjez anga qemonevolj anga ota toa sikinmosalj.
S.TRANSL: In the evening when she comes back there is the second distribution of gifts.

S.FORM: nu małian anga nu qadavan kitsaqis anga, mana zua viliviliłan anga a qemunevuł; sana kialap nu małian anga nu qadavan.
no maljian anga no qadavan kicaqis anga, mana zoa vilivililjan anga a qemonevolj; sana kialap no maljian anga no qadavan.
S.TRANSL: On the next day the bride puts on layers of underpants, and there is a last distribution of gifts. And then on the next day the bride is taken to the bridegroom’s house.

S.FORM: namayatutsu a kakudan nu tja suqatsan.
namayatoco a kakodan no tja soqacan.
S.TRANSL: These are the customs in brief.

S.FORM: łakua nu i tjuqała a vavayan, izua uta a kiniqayaman, a pana a tjekeza, a siniteperuk tua qinałan, a tedek tua tsakar, na maqatsuvutsuvung, a sitjumaq, a sinipakizing.
ljakoa no i tjoqalja a vavayan, izoa ota a kiniqayaman, a pana a tjekeza, a siniteperok toa qinaljan, a tedek toa cakar, na maqacovocovong, a sitjomaq, a sinipakizing.
S.TRANSL: But if the bride is in another village there will also be inspections of rivers and bridges, and compensation for ‘breaking up the village’, decorations for the shrine, the youths’ share, compensation for entering(?) and for food expenses (or for bringing home)(?).

S.FORM: aitsu a siputseketsekeł nua mamazangiłan kadjunangan pana qałuqałupan djilung a kaułayan qata kuang tjakit, izuanan uta a zuma vadis.
aico a sipocekecekelj noa mamazangiljan kadjonangan pana qaljoqaljopan djilong a kaoljayan qata koang tjakit, izoanan ota a zoma vadis.
S.TRANSL: The bride-prices among chieftains include land, rivers, hunting grounds, precious pots, beads, guns and swords; and there is other tribute to be paid as well.

S.FORM: izua uta aza tjiuma ayayain a łałakayan.
izoa ota aza tjioma ayayain a ljaljakayan.
S.TRANSL: There is also a swing set up called a tjiuma.
